item.text: The Experience API ([[xAPI]]), also known as the Tin Can API is an e-learning software specification that allows learning content and learning systems to speak to each other in a manner that records and tracks all types of learning experiences - [https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Experience_API_%28Tin_Can_API%29 wikipedia]
Growth of xAPI transactions - [https://xapi.com/blog/an-exciting-time-to-watch-xapi-and-cmi5-adoption-numbers/?utm_source=google&utm_medium=natural_search xapi.com]
This is an image - [https://2j6vh43zoo92z7qif3oiqt2l-wpengine.netdna-ssl.com/wp-content/uploads/sites/3/2020/12/xAPI-statements-in-SCORM-Cloud-min-1024x656.png netdna-ssl.com]

# Research
Here we list our recent reading and exploration of xAPI which needs to be sorted and organised - [https://www.one-tab.com/page/fpFwCKgtQfGfdWpicRVxSA one-tab.com]:

# Use
The Experience API is growing steadily each year.
Learning experiences are recorded in a Learning Record Store (LRS). LRSs can exist within traditional Learning Management Systems (LMSs) or on their own.
- xAPI: Everything You Need to Know in 2021 - [https://www.devlinpeck.com/xapi-lrs devlinpeck.com]
- xAPI: Everything You Need to Know in 2021 - [https://www.devlinpeck.com/xapi-lrs devlinpeck.com]

# Research
Below we list online references and links we gathered from early group discussions:

item.title: Advanced Distributed Learning
item.text: The vision of the ADL Initiative is to provide access to the highest quality learning and performance aiding that can be tailored to individual needs, and delivered cost effectively at the right time and at the right place.

The Experience API is an open source API. It is a [[RESTful Web Service]] that uses [[JSON]] for its data format. The web service allows software clients to read and write experiential data in the form of "statement" objects.
More complex statement forms can be used. There is also a built in query API to help filter recorded statements, and a state API that allows for a sort of "scratch space" for consuming applications.
In their simplest form, statements are in the form of "I did this", or more generally "actor verb object".
The ability to track games and simulations is becoming ever more important in [[EdTech]].
item.title: Learning Games and Simulations

item.text: Most learning occurs outside of the browser. Pervasive or [[Ubiquitous Learning]] requires these learning experiences to be integrated into the overall framework.
item.title: Learning Outside the Browser

item.text: Group or team-based learning is a core part of [[Viral Academy Methodology]] and is supported by the [[Experience API]].
item.title: Group Learning

item.text: Start learning on a mobile device, finish it on a computer.
item.title: Platform Transition

item.text: The ability to track real-world performance
The ability to track games and simulations
Platform transition; e.g. start e-learning on a mobile device, finish it on a computer
Taking e-learning outside of the web browser

In their simplest form, statements are in the form of ‚ÄúI did this‚Äù, or more generally ‚Äúactor verb object‚Äù. More complex statement forms can be used. There is also a built in query API to help filter recorded statements, and a state API that allows for a sort of ‚Äúscratch space‚Äù for consuming applications.

The Experience API is an open source API. It is a [[RESTful Web Service]] that uses [[JSON]] for its data format. The web service allows software clients to read and write experiential data in the form of ‚Äústatement‚Äù objects.

Taking e-learning outside of the web browser
    E-learning in native mobile applications
    More control over learning content
    Solid security using Oauth
    Platform transition; e.g. start e-learning on a mobile device, finish it on a computer
    The ability to track games and simulations
    The ability to track real-world performance
    Team-based e-learning
    Tracking learning plans and goals
The Experience API (Tin Can API) is commonly considered the successor to [[SCORM]]. The Experience API allows for several new capabilities that SCORM didn't, such as:

Taking e-learning outside of the web browser
    E-learning in native mobile applications
    More control over learning content
    Solid security using Oauth
    Platform transition; e.g. start e-learning on a mobile device, finish it on a computer
    The ability to track games and simulations
    The ability to track real-world performance
    Team-based e-learning
    Tracking learning plans and goals

The Experience API (Tin Can API) is an open source API. It is a Representational state transfer web service that uses JavaScript Object Notation for its data format. The web service allows software clients to read and write experiential data in the form of ‚Äústatement‚Äù objects. In their simplest form, statements are in the form of ‚ÄúI did this‚Äù, or more generally ‚Äúactor verb object‚Äù.[4] More complex statement forms can be used. There is also a built in query API to help filter recorded statements, and a state API that allows for a sort of ‚Äúscratch space‚Äù for consuming applications.
The Experience API (Tin Can API) is commonly considered the successor to [[SCORM]].

The Experience API allows for several new capabilities that SCORM didn't, such as:

    Taking e-learning outside of the web browser[5]
    E-learning in native mobile applications[1]
    More control over learning content[4]
    Solid security using Oauth
    Platform transition; e.g. start e-learning on a mobile device, finish it on a computer[5]
    The ability to track games and simulations[2]
    The ability to track real-world performance[6]
    Team-based e-learning[2]
    Tracking learning plans and goals[7]

The Experience API (Tin Can API) is an open source API. It is a Representational state transfer web service that uses JavaScript Object Notation for its data format. The web service allows software clients to read and write experiential data in the form of ‚Äústatement‚Äù objects. In their simplest form, statements are in the form of ‚ÄúI did this‚Äù, or more generally ‚Äúactor verb object‚Äù.[4] More complex statement forms can be used. There is also a built in query API to help filter recorded statements, and a state API that allows for a sort of ‚Äúscratch space‚Äù for consuming applications.

The Experience API (Tin Can API) is commonly considered the successor to SCORM. SCORM (Sharable Content Object Reference Model) has been the de facto e-learning standard for packaging e-learning content to be delivered to LMSs.[citation needed] However, there are several drawbacks to SCORM.
Learning experiences are recorded in a Learning Record Store (LRS). LRSs can exist within traditional Learning Management Systems (LMSs) or on their own.
Learning experiences are recorded in a Learning Record Store (LRS). LRSs can exist within traditional Learning Management Systems (LMSs) or on their own

The Experience API (xAPI), also known as the Tin Can API is an e-learning software specification that allows learning content and learning systems to speak to each other in a manner that records and tracks all types of learning experiences - [https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Experience_API_%28Tin_Can_API%29 WikiPedia]

The Experience API ([[xAPI]]), also known as the Tin Can API is an e-learning software specification that allows learning content and learning systems to speak to each other in a manner that records and tracks all types of learning experiences - [https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Experience_API_%28Tin_Can_API%29 wikipedia]
However this still represents only a small partion of the overall market:
This is an image - [https://2j6vh43zoo92z7qif3oiqt2l-wpengine.netdna-ssl.com/wp-content/uploads/sites/3/2020/12/Packaged-content-in-SCORM-Cloud-2020-min-1024x633.png netdna-ssl.com]

[[xAPI]] accounts for only 1.4% of learning package imports in 2010 - [https://xapi.com/blog/an-exciting-time-to-watch-xapi-and-cmi5-adoption-numbers/?utm_source=google&utm_medium=natural_search xapi.com]

[[xAPI]] accounts for only 1.4% of learning package imports in 2010 - [https://xapi.com/blog/an-exciting-time-to-watch-xapi-and-cmi5-adoption-numbers/?utm_source=google&utm_medium=natural_search xapi.com]

The Experience API is growing steadily each year:
- [[Growth of xAPI]]

[[xAPI]] looks a good candidate to establish an open global standard for independent learning data. It lives in the [[restful]], [[json-rpc]] centric world, and is fully on the standards track. Adoption may be slow, but it is growing continuously in a conservative market.

The Experience API is growing steadily each year:
- [[Growth of xAPI]]

story.text: The Experience API ([[xAPI]]), also known as the Tin Can API is an e-learning software specification that allows learning content and learning systems to speak to each other in a manner that records and tracks all types of learning experiences - [https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Experience_API_%28Tin_Can_API%29 wikipedia]

- Review 2021 - [https://www.devlinpeck.com/xapi-lrs devlinpeck.com]
- Tutorials | Devlin Peck -... - [https://www.devlinpeck.com/tutorials devlinpeck.com]
- The xAPI Challenges App - [https://www.devlinpeck.com/projects/xapi-challenges-app devlinpeck.com]
# Use

[[xAPI]] looks a good candidate to establish an open global standard for independent learning data. It lives in the [[restful]], [[json-rpc]] centric world, and is fully on the standards track. Adoption may be slow, but it is growing continuously in a conservative market.

The Experience API is growing steadily each year:
- [[Growth of xAPI]]
# How it works
Learning experiences are recorded in a Learning Record Store (LRS). LRSs can exist within traditional Learning Management Systems (LMSs) or on their own.
- [[Advanced Distributed Learning]]
The Experience API (Tin Can API) is commonly considered the successor to [[SCORM]]. The Experience API allows for several new capabilities that SCORM didn't, such as:

The Experience API is an open source API. It is a [[RESTful Web Service]] that uses [[JSON]] for its data format. The web service allows software clients to read and write experiential data in the form of "statement" objects.
In their simplest form, statements are in the form of "I did this", or more generally "actor verb object".
More complex statement forms can be used. There is also a built in query API to help filter recorded statements, and a state API that allows for a sort of "scratch space" for consuming applications.
- [[Learning Outside the Browser]]
- [[Group Learning]]
- [[Learning Games and Simulations]]
- [[Control Over Learning Content]]
- [[Learning Games and Simulations]]
- Tracking learning plans and goals
- [[Livecode xAPI]]
- [[xAPI Learning Cohort]]
